ratings.comment: He's friendly but he's a terrible teacher. He rambles a lot in lecture about random, unrelated topics and the textbook he uses is not all that good either. The one plus is that he's a very lenient grader. But if you want to actually learn and understand experimental design, you should take it with someone else.

I enjoyed taking the course. Professor Chien gave interesting examples of chip production and shared stories about statisticians. We learned methods like two-way ANOVA, Latin square, and factorial design. I suggest attending office hours, as he excels at inspiring thoughts, which gives you opportunities to explore and deepen your understanding.

Peter is nice and he's pretty good at explaining the course topics. He gives a lot of review material for the exams, so you can do well if you try. But, the exams did take most of the class the entire period, so be aware that you'll need to work fast. He's inconsistent at answering Piazza posts, but is very willing to help if you speak to him.

The course contents have already made no sense, and I am not sure what is the meaning of learning those things. His lecture cannot clarify things for me. Prof. Chien is not positive about communicating with our TA, so the discussion is not helpful. His tests are not capable to test one's true ability.

Peter not only excels at explaining statistical formulas, but also goes beyond that to impart a deeper understanding of statistical knowledge. This makes him stand out as one of the best statistics professors I have ever encountered. Additionally, he is incredibly patient and willing to answer all of your questions.
Prof. Chien's class was easy to follow and fun. He covered a variety of topics and gave a lot of practice problems before exams. Peter is an excellent teacher.

Peter is an amazing professor and lecturer. He makes his online class very enjoyable. He explains the materials in a clear, simple way that is easy to follow. He has inspired me to pursue the path of Statistics. He always makes himself available to answer my questions.

There were lots of positive feedbacks about Peter, but this semester he really did poor in teaching. Maybe it is due to the online instruction, he just talked through the problems in class and did not write anything down, which is very hard to understand. Also the grading is super unclear. Did not provide any grade cutoff for exams. AVOID!

Peter is a really nice person, but a really horrible professor. He is about as unorganized and ineffective as a professor can get. He wastes class time and leaves you more confused than when he started. His lectures and examples lack clear direction. He made a class that should have been straightforward unreasonably difficult.

DO NOT be fooled by the positive comments! Here are just a few of the many examples of why Peter is subpar, academically and as an instructor. 1) Failed to answer questions in class 2) Replied to questions in piazza only by saying "TA will address this". It is true that Peter is a nice person, but you would want to avoid him.

Do not take his classes. He's extremely unclear in his instruction, unavailable outside of class, wastes so much class time every single lecture, and when you ask a question he'll literally pick other students to give an answer rather than answering himself. Each exam question is also worth a ton of points with very little option for partial credit

his class may sound boring at first, but it gets better. the exams are almost the same as the practice exams, which is very helpful. for the exams you need to pay close attention for what he says in class, and get ready to read the textbook for supporting materials. homework requires writing R codes, lectures and exams will not.

Professor Chien is really a good person and he inspired you to learn deeper in Statistics. His teaching is really fascinating and useful. I think everyone can learn some from his class. The exam is not too difficult if you follow his instruction and do all required material. He is really good at teaching.

Peter is one of the best stat professors I've ever meet. If you attend the lecture and take the class seriously, you would get an A easily. Peter would give you lots of advice about the final project. Of course, the best way is to talk to him personally about the project, which will make you in the right direction and an A.

His lectures were fine but I really learned the material by reading the book and going to section and listening to the TA. He skimmed project proposals and approved them without actually reading them. Mine had errors that I didn't realise until too late, a friend of mine was told to redo his project with a diff idea even though it was approved...
